User provide high-level research directi.Format: Natural language task descriptions via web interface
User provide high-level research directi.Example: User inputs requests such as 'Searching for synthetic methods that can use air to oxidize alcohols into aldehydes.'
User provide high-level research directi.Role in workflow: Defines the chemical synthesis goal and initiates the workflow.

User provide structured, domain-specific.Format: Natural language specifying variables, constraints, or optimization objectives
User provide structured, domain-specific.Example: User specifies optimization variables: 'I want to optimize four variables: 1. Reaction time: 45–90 min; 2. Base volume: 0.125-0.25 mL; 3. Cu catalyst: CuCl2, CuBr2, Cu(OTf)2, Cu(BF4)2; 4. Base type: NMI, DBU.'
User provide structured, domain-specific.Role in workflow: Constrains and guides experimental design and optimization.

User provide research papers.Format: Upload or reference of literature documents
User provide research papers.Example: User uploads literature for extraction of procedures and design space.
User provide research papers.Role in workflow: Provides grounding for extraction of experimental protocols and chemical knowledge.

User provide representations or formal i.Format: Chemical structures, reaction schemes, or code snippets in natural language or structured JSON
User provide representations or formal i.Example: User provides substrate structures or requests code for OT-2 liquid handler.
User provide representations or formal i.Role in workflow: Enables translation to machine-executable protocols and chemical reasoning.

Query Decomposition.Method details: LLM-based agents break down user queries into sub-tasks (e.g., literature search, extraction, experiment design).
Query Decomposition.Outputs: Sub-queries for agents (e.g., method search, extraction, optimization)
Query Decomposition.Example: User asks for method search, then for extraction of procedure, then for optimization.
Query Decomposition.Role in workflow: Enables targeted retrieval and sequential workflow execution.

Structural or Entity Decomposition.Method details: Agents identify and extract chemical entities (substrates, catalysts, bases) from literature and user input.
Structural or Entity Decomposition.Outputs: Lists of chemicals, variables, and experimental parameters
Structural or Entity Decomposition.Example: Extraction of Cu salts, bases, and time options from literature.

Workflow Decomposition.Method details: Multi-agent system assigns specialized agents to sequential subtasks (e.g., Literature Scouter, Experiment Designer, Hardware Executor, etc.).
Workflow Decomposition.Inputs: User task descriptions and extracted information
Workflow Decomposition.Example: LLM-RDF assigns literature search, then experiment design, then execution, then analysis.
Workflow Decomposition.Role in workflow: Creates actionable, multi-step plans for end-to-end synthesis.

Textual or Knowledge Embedding.Method details: Vector search technology used for semantic retrieval from Semantic Scholar.
Textual or Knowledge Embedding.Outputs: Relevant literature based on semantic similarity
Textual or Knowledge Embedding.Example: Literature Scouter uses vector search to find methods for aerobic alcohol oxidation.

Pattern and Feature Extraction.Method details: Spectrum Analyzer extracts features (peaks, retention times, yields) from GC-FID-MS and NMR data.
Pattern and Feature Extraction.Outputs: Identified peaks, calculated yields, concentration profiles
Pattern and Feature Extraction.Example: Automated identification of product and substrate peaks in GC-MS data.
Pattern and Feature Extraction.Role in workflow: Automates data analysis and result interpretation.

Property and Annotation Extraction.Method details: Extraction of reaction conditions, yields, and selectivity from literature and experimental data.
Property and Annotation Extraction.Outputs: Structured tables of conditions, yields, and selectivity
Property and Annotation Extraction.Example: Extraction of design space: Cu salts, bases, time from literature.

Data Retrieval via Multi-Query Generatio.Method details: LLM agents generate follow-up queries based on initial user requests (e.g., method search, best method, procedure extraction).
Data Retrieval via Multi-Query Generatio.Example: After initial method search, agent is asked which method is best, then to extract procedures.
Data Retrieval via Multi-Query Generatio.Role in workflow: Expands literature exploration and evidence gathering.

Literature and Data Retrieval via APIs.Method details: Literature Scouter agent queries Semantic Scholar via Consensus API for academic literature.
Literature and Data Retrieval via APIs.Example: Retrieving methods for aerobic alcohol oxidation from Semantic Scholar.
Literature and Data Retrieval via APIs.Role in workflow: Provides up-to-date, referenced literature for downstream tasks.

Data Retrieval with Prioritization and F.Method details: Literature Scouter recommends most practical methods based on criteria (e.g., sustainability, selectivity).
Data Retrieval with Prioritization and F.Example: Agent recommends Cu/TEMPO system as most practical.
Data Retrieval with Prioritization and F.Role in workflow: Focuses workflow on most promising approaches.

Domain-Specific Data Retrieval and Reaso.Method details: Agents extract and reason over domain-specific details (e.g., reaction conditions, substrate scope) from literature.
Domain-Specific Data Retrieval and Reaso.Outputs: Extracted protocols, design spaces, and mechanistic insights
Domain-Specific Data Retrieval and Reaso.Example: Extraction of procedure and design space for Cu/TEMPO oxidation.

Code-Driven or Tool-Augmented Data Retri.Method details: Agents generate Python code to analyze raw experimental data (e.g., GC-MS, NMR) and retrieve results.
Code-Driven or Tool-Augmented Data Retri.Example: Spectrum Analyzer writes Python code to process GC-MS data.
Code-Driven or Tool-Augmented Data Retri.Role in workflow: Automates data analysis and result extraction.

Literature data Retrieval via Semantic a.Method details: Vector search enables semantic retrieval of literature matching user queries.
Literature data Retrieval via Semantic a.Example: Finding recent methods for alcohol oxidation using vector search.
Literature data Retrieval via Semantic a.Role in workflow: Ensures contextually relevant literature is retrieved.

Domain-Specific Literature data Retrieva.Method details: Agents use chemistry-specific keywords and context to retrieve targeted literature.
Domain-Specific Literature data Retrieva.Example: Searching for 'synthetic methods that can use air to oxidize alcohols into aldehydes.'
Domain-Specific Literature data Retrieva.Role in workflow: Targets literature relevant to the chemical domain.

Manual and Semi-Automatic Curation of Li.Method details: Human chemists review and select among agent-recommended methods and extracted protocols.
Manual and Semi-Automatic Curation of Li.Outputs: Final selection of methods and protocols
Manual and Semi-Automatic Curation of Li.Example: Manual evaluation of recommended methods for practical application.
Manual and Semi-Automatic Curation of Li.Role in workflow: Ensures correctness and relevance of selected approaches.

Standardized Section Extraction from Lit.Method details: Literature Scouter extracts procedures, design spaces, and options from uploaded papers.
Standardized Section Extraction from Lit.Example: Extraction of procedure: 'To a solution of alcohol in CH3CN...'
Standardized Section Extraction from Lit.Role in workflow: Normalizes literature content for downstream use.

Concise Synopsis and Summarization of Li.Method details: Agents summarize key findings and practical aspects of literature methods.
Concise Synopsis and Summarization of Li.Outputs: Summaries of method advantages and limitations
Concise Synopsis and Summarization of Li.Example: Summarizing why Cu/TEMPO system is most practical.
Concise Synopsis and Summarization of Li.Role in workflow: Guides method selection and experimental planning.

Facet-Based or Field-Specific Extraction.Method details: Extraction of specific fields such as catalyst type, base, solvent, and time from literature.
Facet-Based or Field-Specific Extraction.Outputs: Tables of experimental variables and options
Facet-Based or Field-Specific Extraction.Example: Design space: Cu salts, bases, time options.

Domain-Tailored Extraction from Literatu.Method details: Extraction of chemoselectivity, substrate compatibility, and mechanistic insights.
Domain-Tailored Extraction from Literatu.Outputs: Domain-specific knowledge (e.g., selectivity for primary alcohols)
Domain-Tailored Extraction from Literatu.Example: Recognition that Cu/TEMPO system selectively oxidizes primary alcohols.
Domain-Tailored Extraction from Literatu.Role in workflow: Informs experimental design and mechanistic reasoning.

Idea/hypothesis generation without addit.Method details: LLM-based agents propose experimental modifications or troubleshooting based on internal knowledge.
Idea/hypothesis generation without addit.Outputs: Suggestions for solvent change, catalyst choice, etc.
Idea/hypothesis generation without addit.Example: Experiment Designer suggests switching to higher boiling point solvent due to volatility issues.
Idea/hypothesis generation without addit.Role in workflow: Generates new experimental ideas beyond literature.

LLM Agent Generate ideas/hypotheses via.Method details: Agents decompose tasks (e.g., screening, optimization, scale-up) and generate ideas for each step.
LLM Agent Generate ideas/hypotheses via.Example: Suggesting two-stage scale-up strategy for gas-liquid biphasic reaction.
LLM Agent Generate ideas/hypotheses via.Role in workflow: Structures idea generation across workflow stages.

Generate ideas/hypotheses using Domain-S.Method details: Specialized agents (e.g., Experiment Designer, Result Interpreter) generate domain-specific hypotheses and explanations.
Generate ideas/hypotheses using Domain-S.Example: Result Interpreter explains observed selectivity trends.
Generate ideas/hypotheses using Domain-S.Role in workflow: Provides expert-level reasoning for hypothesis generation.

Literature data used during idea/hypothe.Method details: Agents use extracted literature procedures and findings to inform hypothesis and protocol generation.
Literature data used during idea/hypothe.Example: Using literature procedure as basis for HTS design.

Summarization Literature data used durin.Method details: Summarized literature findings are used to guide agent recommendations.
Summarization Literature data used durin.Example: Summarizing substrate scope and selectivity from literature.
Summarization Literature data used durin.Role in workflow: Focuses idea generation on key findings.

Idea/hypothesis generation via Pattern D.Method details: Agents analyze HTS and kinetic data to detect patterns (e.g., yield trends, selectivity).
Idea/hypothesis generation via Pattern D.Outputs: Pattern-based hypotheses (e.g., effect of electron-withdrawing groups)
Idea/hypothesis generation via Pattern D.Example: Result Interpreter notes higher reactivity with electron-withdrawing groups.

Idea/hypothesis generation using Observa.Method details: Agents use observed experimental outcomes to refine mechanistic or optimization hypotheses.
Idea/hypothesis generation using Observa.Example: Explaining lack of reactivity for certain diols based on observed data.

LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Method details: Agents assess practicality, selectivity, and efficiency of methods and conditions.
LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Example: Literature Scouter recommends Cu/TEMPO system for practical applications.
LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Role in workflow: Focuses workflow on high-quality, feasible approaches.

LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Method details: Agents evaluate hypotheses against chemical criteria (e.g., yield, selectivity, cost).
LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Example: Result Interpreter evaluates optimization stopping based on yield and exploration.

LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Method details: Agents integrate literature and experimental evidence to support or reject hypotheses.
LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Example: Manual evaluation of agent recommendations for method selection.

LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Method details: Agents use metrics such as yield, selectivity, and reproducibility to assess success.
LLM-based Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via.Role in workflow: Guides decision to continue or stop experiments.

Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via Quantitat.Method details: Agents and Bayesian optimization use quantitative metrics (e.g., probability of improvement, R2 for kinetic fits).
Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via Quantitat.Example: Stopping optimization based on PI threshold or agent recommendation.

Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via Human/Exp.Method details: Human chemists review agent outputs for correctness and completeness.
Hypothesis/Idea evaluation via Human/Exp.Example: Manual inspection before executing agent-generated code.

Experimental Design Generation via liter.Method details: Agents extract and adapt experimental protocols directly from literature.
Experimental Design Generation via liter.Outputs: Experimental protocols for screening, kinetics, optimization
Experimental Design Generation via liter.Example: Extracting and adapting Cu/TEMPO oxidation procedure.
Experimental Design Generation via liter.Role in workflow: Provides validated starting points for experiments.

Experimental Design Generation via Liter.Method details: Agents synthesize literature and user constraints to generate new protocols (e.g., solvent change, scale-up strategy).
Experimental Design Generation via Liter.Example: Switching to DMSO solvent based on volatility issue.

Experimental Design Generation via Execu.Method details: Agents generate OT-2 Python code from extracted protocols for automated execution.
Experimental Design Generation via Execu.Example: Hardware Executor generates code for OT-2 to run HTS.

LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Method details: Agents autonomously plan experimental sequences (e.g., HTS, kinetics, optimization, scale-up).
LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Example: Experiment Designer plans sampling schedule for kinetics.

LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Method details: Agents translate experimental plans into machine-executable code and JSON protocols.
LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Example: Generating OT-2 code from JSON protocol.

LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Method details: Specialized agents (e.g., Experiment Designer, Hardware Executor, Spectrum Analyzer) collaborate to design, execute, and analyze experiments.
LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Example: Agents coordinate for HTS, analysis, and interpretation.

LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Method details: Agents map hypotheses to concrete lab techniques and apparatus (e.g., OT-2, HPLC, Big Kahuna).
LLM-Based Experimental Design Generation.Example: Mapping optimization task to Big Kahuna and HPLC.

Test Execution via Human-in-the-Loop.Method details: Human chemists review, approve, and sometimes manually execute or supervise agent-generated experiments.
Test Execution via Human-in-the-Loop.Example: Manual TLC and column chromatography guided by agent recommendations.

Test Execution via Automated Wet-Lab Exe.Method details: Automated platforms (OT-2, Big Kahuna, HPLC) execute agent-generated protocols without manual intervention.
Test Execution via Automated Wet-Lab Exe.Example: OT-2 runs HTS and sampling; Big Kahuna runs optimization.

Test Execution via Computational or In-S.Method details: Finite element analysis (FEniCS) used for current distribution simulation in photoelectrochemical reactor design.
Test Execution via Computational or In-S.Example: Result Interpreter uses FEniCS to simulate current in FTO photoanode.
Test Execution via Computational or In-S.Role in workflow: Validates and optimizes reactor design computationally.

Refinement via LLM Agent Feedback Loops.Method details: Agents iteratively critique and refine protocols and hypotheses based on test outcomes.
Refinement via LLM Agent Feedback Loops.Example: Result Interpreter suggests stopping optimization after plateau in yield.
Refinement via LLM Agent Feedback Loops.Role in workflow: Improves workflow efficiency and outcome quality.

Refinement via Automated Quality Evaluat.Method details: Bayesian optimization and statistical metrics (e.g., PI, R2) used to evaluate and refine experimental conditions.
Refinement via Automated Quality Evaluat.Example: Stopping optimization based on PI threshold.

Refinement via Dynamic Agent Updating Ba.Method details: Agents update experimental plans in response to new data (e.g., switching solvents, adjusting sampling schedules).
Refinement via Dynamic Agent Updating Ba.Example: Changing solvent to DMSO after volatility issue observed.

Refinement via guided by computational-d.Method details: Refinement of hypotheses and protocols based on computational analysis of test results (e.g., kinetic model fitting).
Refinement via guided by computational-d.Example: Adjusting kinetic model parameters after NMR analysis.

Refinement via experimental validation.Method details: Experimental outcomes (e.g., yields, purities) inform further protocol refinement and troubleshooting.
Refinement via experimental validation.Example: Iterative TLC to optimize eluent composition.

Refinement via Performance-metric.Method details: Performance metrics (yield, purity, current uniformity) guide further optimization and stopping decisions.
Refinement via Performance-metric.Example: Selecting scale-up conditions based on yield and cost.

Refinement via Human–data integration.Method details: Human chemists provide feedback and integrate raw data for agent-driven refinement.
Refinement via Human–data integration.Example: Manual review of agent-generated code before execution.

paper_title: An automatic end-to-end chemical synthesis development platform powered by large language models
